title: How to find collaborators for a project - Quora

response.answer_text: I have been working in the field of media collaboration for quite some time, so my approach might help you. You should always contact the person or the organization with whom you wish to collaborate through E-mail . Never call them directly or text them , it might negatively impact the image of the organization and is unprofessional at the same time.Things to include in the mailA catchy subject , like Media collaboration , media partnership or collaboration proposal etc ., would work.Brief introduction about you or your organization.Purpose of writing the mail - mention why you wish to collaborate with them.Attach the proposal file with the mail for better communication of the deliverables .( at the end of the answer check out what to include in a proposal file )Insert link of your social media handles or websites for their reference.3. Provide your contact number, ask them if they could connect with you on a call for better communication. 4. Keep the mail short don't make it too long people really don't read it. Just mention the important points . Collaboration Proposal A collaboration proposal can be a one page doc or 2 to 3 page pdf depending upon what you wish to include . Ideally a collaboration proposal includes the deliverables . In other words a list of things you have to offer and you expect in return from the other person. If you are looking for a paid collaboration then you mention the amount that you can offer or if it's unpaid then mention the deliverables that you can or may offer and expect in return . Mention in your proposal and mail that the deliverables are negotiable( only if you wish to negotiate else dont mention) it increase the chances of the person reverting if he or she finds your deliverables unacceptable or has some doubt for that matter. The proposal should include the term of collaboration that you expect and other relevant information that you want your prospective collaborator to know beforehand. I have pretty much covered important points . Hope this helps :)

If you’re interested in collaborating with someone in your community, the best way to approach them is to just reach out and start the conversation. Come prepared with at least one idea for how you’d like to collaborate, but be open to adjusting the idea once you learn more about what they’re focusing on as a business. The language I recommend my clients use when reaching out is something to the effect of: “I have a collaboration idea I’d love to run by you, but it’d be great to learn more about what you’re focusing on in the coming months as a business to see if there are other ways we might be able to support one another through collaboration.” The most important thing you can do to increase the likelihood of someone saying “yes” to a collaboration is to approach them in a way that feels like you’re going to make their life easier by partnering with you. Put yourself in their shoes, and lead with their goals in mind so the idea doesn’t feel like more work for them. Of course, you must also make sure that it’s worth it for you as well, but when doing the initial outreach frame it in a way that doesn’t scare them off with an unformed, one-sided collaboration idea. I’ve answered this question and tons more about collaboration here if you’re interested in learning more: Collaboration Nation: This Expert Answers All Your Questions on an Essential Practice to Business Growth
